Moving to California

June 27, 2014       Norfolk, UK

The Task

"Please write a paragraph or two about what you are hoping to get out of your time abroad, these can be personal or academic achievements. Also how you think this experience will change you."

America is a BIG challenge. Period. That said I think (read know) a lot can gained from it personally, professionally and maybe academically. So let's start with the academic. According to the Times Educational Supplement Cal is ranked 8th in the world. Restrict it to physical sciences and it moves up to 5th (above Cambridge might I add.) Consider that York only just sneaks in to the top 100 overall, but then fails to get in when you restrict to physical sciences it puts in to perspective the challenge that classes will bring. Academically I hope this means it will be stimulating and I hope that I can gain a lot from the different teaching style, students and connections I can make. If anyone knows contacts at the university, now would be the time to write them in the comments. Please? Situated an hour north of Silicon valley I could not possibly be in a better suited area of the world to be positively influenced. The American system will allow me to explore a wider variety of modules in Computer Science and physics, so I hope to come out the other side with a much broader education and skill set than I would have by staying in England. Ultimate Frisbee is a huge part of my life and I constantly moan about the weather. To put it bluntly, that shouldn't be a problem in California. With average conditions of our summer for the college season, I don't think that I'll have a problem motivating myself to get to sessions and developing my play. With a view looking over the Golden Gate bridge for some of the pitches, my only concern is that I'm going to get distracted by the place. Not the Frisbee.
